questions.question_text:
A hospital's security team recently determined its network was breached and patient data was accessed by an external entity. The Chief Information Security
Officer (CISO) of the hospital approaches the executive management team with this information, reports the vulnerability that led to the breach has already been remediated, and explains the team is continuing to follow the appropriate incident response plan. The executive team is concerned about the hospital's brand reputation and asks the CISO when the incident should be disclosed to the affected patients. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate response?

discussion.content: patient data have legal responsibilities and regulations talk to the lawyers first.
A. When it is mandated by their legal and regulatory requirements
Seems like in general with PHI and health related information being disclosed, you should always refer to the law or talk to lawyers.

I would think either:
E. Upon the approval of the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) to release information to the public
or
A. When it is mandated by their legal and regulatory requirements

The CEO should have the final say-so. And the CEO would, almost certainly, go along with legal requirements. But what about the unlikely case where the CEO refuses to disclose the data? In that case, I suppose, you would disclose the data anyway. Better to be fired than on the hook for breaking the law.
D. When all steps related to the incident response plan are completed

choices.C: As soon as the public relations department is ready to be interviewed
choices.E: Upon the approval of the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) to release information to the public
choices.B: As soon as possible in the interest of the patients
choices.A: When it is mandated by their legal and regulatory requirements
choices.D: When all steps related to the incident response plan are completed

discussion.content: Slightly OT: does static code analysis tell you if the code is secure, or does it just tell you if the code will work? In my experience, static code analyzers, that are embedded in the IDE, only tell you if there are coding errors. For example, they will not tell you if you need to use some kind of input verification.

Here's my analysis of this question. The team doesn't want assessment activities during deployment, this means options involving the production environment are out. So C and D are no-gos. A UAT isn't a good way to test for security. Answer A can only test for static, so that meants it won't be through the entire SDLC environment. My guess is E, since it means that the product is assessed through the entire environment, without being intrusive to their live environment.

I would choose A. As crazy as that sounds, SCA tools can help developers identify vulnerabilities and security issues at the time of code commit into the repo. This as early as development phase itself and before peer review and well before UAT. Not all tools support this bit i think thats what the question is after.

comments.content:
The question asks for "assessing security throughout the life cycle"
That would mean during development, and production. I don't know if any of the options really address that.

discussion.content: This is a bogus question that I hope doesn't show up on the actual test. I feel like it could be any one of these, ugh.
Just check this question with development team and answer is B,

B is correct

questions.question_text:
A deployment manager is working with a software development group to assess the security of a new version of the organization's internally developed ERP tool.
The organization prefers to not perform assessment activities following deployment, instead focusing on assessing security throughout the life cycle. Which of the following methods would BEST assess the security of the product?

discussion.content:
ISA – Interconnection Security Aggreement – Agreement on the security standards between organizations.
BIA – Business Impact Analysis – Vulnerability assessments, evaluations etc.
SLA – Service level agreement – Agreed service standards.
RA – Risk assessment.

(A)

A. ISA
A document that regulates security-relevant aspects of an intended connection between an agency and an external system. It regulates the security interface between any two systems operating under two different distinct authorities

Selected Answer: A
When we want to set up a "business-to-business VPN between the two organizations" we should be thinking ISA. So answer should the 'A'.

Selected Answer: A
ISA – Interconnection Security Aggreement – Agreement on the security standards between organizations.

Selected Answer: A
100% A

The correct answer is SLA: The scenario says the 2 businesses agree to share HR Services (key word) and says that they need documentation in order to set up the VPN. In order to get the IT team to establish the VPN, you would need to provide them with the document stating why you would need it via the SLA.
ISA- This agreement is specifically used for laying out the interconnection security requirements for establishing the connection.
Answer is A
A. ISA
SLA - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service-level_agreement

comments.content: In case this comment puts anyone on the fence, it literally cannot be an SLA. The keywords with SLAs are guarantees or promises, ISA keywords are any mention of connecting security systems in any way. This is 110% an ISA.

During a security event investigation, a junior analyst fails to create an image of a server's hard drive before removing the drive and sending it to the forensics analyst. Later, the evidence from the analysis is not usable in the prosecution of the attackers due to the uncertainty of tampering. Which of the following should the junior analyst have followed?

discussion.content:
This is an awful question. Have been involved heavily in digital forensics and none of these answers are what I am looking for. The question is just downright stupid. Of all of these I would have to go with C. Briefly thought Chain of Custody, but the junior never even made a copy of the drive and handed it off to a senior resulting in modification to original HDD. 

Unfortunately, C really isn't what I would be looking for either because the order of volatility just addresses what data needs to be gathered first -> last. I thought D briefly but even that really does not fit. I can't wait for the day CompTIA exams stop being accepted as a test of knowledge.

Selected Answer: C
Because the computer is vulnerable to cyberattacks, cybercriminals can counterfeit and fabricate evidence stored on the computer in question. The forensic analysts must protect the evidence from loss. Before examining the computer for digital evidence, the entire drive of the computer should be imaged (copied) to preserve data and verify its integrity.

Answer is C

C is not the answer.
"Later, the evidence from the analysis is not usable in the prosecution of the attackers due to the uncertainty of tampering" this is more related to chain of customer. 
Here it is not saying that the evident collected was damage, but instead it is saying the evidence was not usable in not usable in the prosecution of the attackers due to the uncertainty of tampering. Pretty much, they can't tell if the attacker or someone else messed with the evidence... that's my understanding on this.
Another really crappy question that's not actually testing your knowledge of these definitions, but I'd have to go with C, as well.
The answer is C with regard to the reference above
I agree the chain of custody is necessary, but I don't believe that is our issue. Forensic analysis should be done on the clone drive, correct? Leaning toward C here.

comments.content: Here I am putting my foot in my mouth again. “Cannot be used because of the uncertainty of tampering”...... B has to be correct based on that.

discussion.content: While this question is very confusingly worded, I do believe answer C is correct. Taking a snapshot of the drive would have preserved all the swap files, which are highly volatile and would likely be destroyed during forensic analysis. While I disagree that this would prevent prosecution, you should always snapshot or archive full disk images before you remove them and send them away so you have an in-time image of the bit arrangement of the drive (including temporary files). Since there is no question as to who had possession of the drive at any time, it is not B a chain of custody issue. Take in-time snapshots of drives as potential evidence before running forensics on the data.

According to NIST, a chain of custody is the process that tracks the movement of evidence through its collection, safeguarding, and analysis lifecycle by documenting each person who handled the evidence, the date/time it was collected, or transferred, and the purpose for the transfer. https://csrc.nist.gov/glossary/term/chain_of_custody#:~:text=Definition(s)%3A,the%20purpose%20for%20the%20transfer.

Based on the above definition, the given answer C is correct.

comments.content: Incorrect - Chain of Custody The concept of chain of custody is used to address the reliability and credibility of evidence. Chain of custody is all about the following questions: Who collected the evidence? Where was the evidence collected? How was the evidence stored? Why was it removed from storage? And who had possession of the evidence during this time? Chain of custody begins when evidence is seized and continues until the evidence is disposed of or returned to the owner.

discussion.content: chain of custody is correct.
B. Chain of custody
